adriaan monshouwer
business stategist & consultant at pictureinside.nl; visual stories editor, curator & connector at onlinephotoeditor.nl; former secretary of the jury of WPPF
Dec 26, 2016

Facebook and the future of news

Who is responsible for the state of legacy media?

Facebook has been dominating the news of late. A growing chorus of voices blame Facebook and Google for the economic problems that many legacy publishers face. In addition, the results of the US presidential election raised the issue of Facebook’s editorial function. In this narrative, Facebook threatens the free press and our values including democracy itself.

This is an enticing story for those working in legacy media, for publishers and journalists alike. Is it accurate? Does it put the blame where it belongs?

A defunct business model

There is no question we continue to see rapid economic changes in media. For example, shifts in both advertiser’s tastes and reader behavior forced the Guardian Media Group to severely cut their digital operations in the US. Estimates are that from all new digital ad dollars spent, 85 percent goes to Facebook and Google. According to Alan Rusbringer, former editor-in-chief of the Guardian, the newspaper lost $27 million in advertising revenue to Facebook, a situation which “is going to get worse because they have a means of distribution we simply can’t cope with.”

Newspaper paid circulation (data from Canada, US and UK) has been in steady decline since the introduction of television in the 1950’s, long before the Internet was invented or Facebook became available for non-students (2006). Television exposed the flaws and vulnerability of legacy media’s underlying business model. Advertising peaked in 2000 and it was back at the 1950’s level in 2013.

In terms of business model, newspapers, news websites, and magazines are multi-sided platforms that facilitate the interaction between two groups of stakeholders: readers/subscribers and advertisers. For readers, content is key. Their perception of the world is largely based upon information by media. For advertisers, content is just the umfelt, the context in which to deliver their commercial message.

Thanks to advertisers, readers paid only a fraction of the real costs of their daily news and advertisers reached the mass audience they wanted. It was a happy arrangement until a new mass media saw the light: television.

If you don’t repair the leak, eventually the boat will sink.

The alarming realization today is that publishers never developed an alternative, sustainable business model.

Instead of blaming others for their poor performance, publishers could better practice some introspection, analyzing where and how they went astray. Unfortunately, self-critique is usually poorly developed amongst publishers and journalists as some political lobbying in the UK demonstrates.

The Media Reform Coalition and the National Union of Journalists are trying to persuade British politicians to amend the new digital economy bill. The amendment proposes a 1 percent levy on the operations of Facebook and Google in order to pay for independent, non-profit journalism. The money would then be used to produce original, local or investigative news reporting.

The Media Reform Coalition argues that the two digital giants “amass eye-watering profits and pay minimal tax in the UK, they are also bleeding the newspaper industry dry by sucking up advertising revenue.”

Notwithstanding its undoubtedly good intentions, the MRC misses the point: news media and serious journalism need to re-invent themselves to stay relevant for readers and other stakeholders. Things have to change in order to stay the same: independent, unbiased, critical and respected. A free press built on a tax levy has all the ingredients of an oxymoron.

Reach

Publishers have the content, but not a big enough audience; Facebook and Google make no content, but have audience in abundance because their reach is unprecedented in media history. This seems like a win-win situation, but unfortunately it is not a win for publishers.

In a recent interview in the Financial Times, Mathias Döpfner — CEO of German media group Axel Springer SE and President of the Federation of German Newspaper Publishers — urged Facebook (and Google) to change their attitude for publishers to survive. He paints a bleak future for all of us if they don’t:

If there is not a real, sufficient and big business model on the search-driven side … and there is no business model at all on the social [media] side, the number of content producers will deteriorate fast. You will have a monopoly of content distribution that will be mainly driven by user-generated content, and by professional content by commercially interested players. You will have a total mix-up of rumor and facts — a pretty traumatic scenario of information or propaganda. It will be very painful for democracies.

Publishers simply cannot monetize the vast audience they reach through the third-party digital platforms of Facebook and Google. What Döpfner means when he says “change their attitude” is unclear, but it could mean paying a fair licensing fee to the content owners and/or publishers.

Licensing fees are not uncommon in digital media. Netflix pays approximately $3 billion in licensing and production fees each year to the television and film industry; Hulu is paying $192 million to license South Park; and while individual artists see less returns than they should, Spotify pays out 70 percent of its gross revenues to the music labels that hold the underlying rights to Spotify’s catalog.

Paying for content through syndication might still be considered a standard publishing business model by many, but Facebook and other digital platforms see it differently. They look at distributing content basically as a free service to both publishers and public.

Michael Wolff — author of Television is the New Television: The Unexpected Triumph of Old Media in the Digital Age — believes publishers can only blame themselves:

Publishers have largely found themselves in this dismal situation because of their past bad decisions — accepting the general free ethos, bowing to a vast catchall of casual and formal sharing and reposting agreements, and failing to challenge an ever-expanding interpretation of fair use. It seems only logical to doubt the business acumen of people who have been singularly inept when it comes to protecting their interests in the world of digital distribution.

Enemy of the state

With Facebook and friends in the driver’s seat, Mathias Döpfner knows where we are heading:

You will have a monopoly of content distribution that will be mainly driven by user-generated content, and by professional content by commercially interested players. You will have a total mix-up of rumor and facts — a pretty traumatic scenario of information or propaganda. It will be very painful for democracies.

It is a warning that echoes the point of the view of the MRC which emphasizes the need for an independent news system to defend democracy and put the public interest first. However, for legacy media to take the moral high ground and proclaim themselves the guardians of democracy is another part of the narrative that needs to be seriously questioned.

In his 2008 book Flat Earth News, the award-winning investigative reporter Nick Davies warns that journalism — the business of reporting the truth — was seriously threatened by the dismantling of infrastructure and the lack of resources to dig up stories or even simply check the facts. He feared the invasion of content generated by the PR industry to fill the news pages.

His book starts with a reconstruction of probably the biggest hoax of our time: the Millennium bug. In 1999, newspapers and magazines all over the world reported for many months about the devastating, life-threatening effects likely to be forthcoming when computers everywhere would crash at 0:00 hours on 1 January 2000. When the time came, nothing happened, or more precisely, nothing was reported. The big story turned out to be a non-story. According to Davies:

This is Flat Earth news. A story appears to be true. It is widely accepted to be true. It becomes a heresy to suggest it is not true — even if it is riddled with falsehood, distortion and propaganda.

And this was years before the birth of Facebook.

“Lügenpresse” — lie press — chanted German protesters — when they rallied in 2014 against the ‘Islamisation of Europe’ — criticizing the media for its reporting on the refugee crisis. These protesters were convinced that German media were very selective in their reporting of events and did not write about incidents that would shed a bad light on refugees and the German immigration policy. Lügenpresse crossed the ocean this year to surface again during the Donald Trump campaign.

The protesters did not refer to Facebook when they shouted this accusation recycled from the 1930s, but to legacy media. These protesters were citizens that had lost faith and did not believe the media to be independent and impartial anymore. Restoring that trust is crucial for legacy media to survive and stay relevant.

To be or not to be

Legacy media play a diminishing role in the consumption of news for a growing number of people.

According to the Reuters Institute Digital News Report — analyzing news consumption in 26 countries — 51 percent of the respondents say they use social media as a source of news each week, and for 12 percent it is their main source. Facebook is by far the most important network for finding, reading, watching, and sharing news. News that is being produced by legacy and other media. In the age group of 18–24 years, 28 percent indicates that social media is the main source of news (more than television’s 24 percent).

For the advocates of a free-flow of information, Facebook does a great — and growing—job in distributing news. News has become a more important part of the Facebook mix, its algorithms prioritizing breaking news, news-related videos, live streams and other visual content.

The report finds strong concerns amongst respondents that algorithmic selection and personalization of news misses out on important information or challenging viewpoints. Frederic Filloux, editor of the Monday Note, observes:

Based on navel-gazing prophecies, news companies started to believe they were indispensable to the Facebook ecosystem as their production was in fact crucial to the social newsfeed.[..] With their usual sense of entitlement, legacy media began to feel that Facebook actually owed them something, at least a recognition for granting the nerdy social network the majestic anointment of their brands.

Talking to a publisher of a renowned investigative US media site, Filloux learns:

After meeting people with good knowledge of Facebook’s inner plumbing, they [the publisher] had come to the conclusion that the algorithm was simply biased to favor positive content over the darker pieces that make the bulk of investigative journalism.

Filloux is convinced that Facebook’s content strategy for the future is visible in its plans for Facebook Live. The Wall Street Journal reports that Facebook will spend $50 million encouraging media companies to create video content. The distribution of the money and the list of companies offer an insight: Buzzfeed and The New York Times get $3 million each and are on top of the list. The New York Times is the only legacy organization in the top 18 of the list, which includes digital natives, specialist short video producers, football clubs FC Barcelona and Real Madrid, and the celebrities Michal Phelps and Gordon Ramsay.

Facebook does not owe legacy media anything and partners with content providers that will seduce their audience to visit the platform more often and stay longer. Facebook’s only interest and goal is to keep users happy.

Facebook — in the words of Marc Zuckerberg — is a technology company, not a media company. At this year’s annual meeting of the Online News Association in Denver, however, Facebook’s director of product Fidji Simo phrased it slightly differently:

We play a big role in the media industry and we take that responsibility very seriously. The reason we primarily consider ourselves a technology company is because we don’t create content, and we are not in the business of picking which topic the world should care about. What we really care about is making everyone have an experience in News Feed where they see what they want to see.

Facebook does not play by the traditional rules of journalism that govern legacy media and investigative digital platforms. Whether it will eventually embrace and pay for serious journalistic reporting is in the hands of its users, who always get what they want (at least, according to Facebook’s Fidji Simo).

It is highly unlikely that the future of in-depth, investigative reporting is in ink and paper. The future will be digital and written in code. Technology and editorial will have to converge in order for journalism to survive.

The odds don’t look strong for legacy media, as their pockets are shallow and empty, but they still have the capability for creating great content. Their challenge is to connect with the right audience. The New York Times is optimistic: “The ambition of having 10 million digital subscribers is possible for us,” according to its CEO, Mark Thompson.

And that is the best news coming out of the US in recent weeks.

Thanks to David Campbell.
